He's not going to say, hey, listen, get your life straightened up because I'm coming back next Tuesday. No, no, in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye. Is that not what the Bible teaches? So why is Paul so concerned about this thing? Why is Paul living his life in the manner in which he is, this desire of being accepted of him has just led to a dedication in his life that I'm laboring, I'm striving, I'm exercising. Why? Because I want God to be pleased with my life. And this morning, every believer in Corinth and every believer throughout the church age that has read this portion of Scripture should have the same desire, should have the same desire, I want to please my Savior. How often do we examine our lives to truly determine if God is pleased? My thoughts. God knows your thoughts. You can hide your thoughts for a period of time. You can hide your thoughts from other people. Why do I say for a period of time? Because your thoughts eventually are going to become your actions. But for a period of time, your thoughts can be hidden from other people, but God knows them. God knows what you're thinking. Do you remember when Jesus stood there and as He's ministering and those people are reasoning amongst themselves and He says, why do you think this in your heart? Can you imagine how they must have thought at that moment? How do you know what I'm thinking? You ever look at your spouse and you kind of can just see and you say, I know what you're thinking. You might be wrong when you say, I know what you're thinking. But God knows exactly what we're thinking. We think about my thoughts being pleasing to God, my words being pleasing to God. My actions. Thoughts lead to words, lead to actions. In this age in which we live, I wonder this morning if my electronic communication is pleasing to God. The text that I send, the emails that I send, the whatever social media posts. Listen, sometimes people just throw stuff out there and they think that it doesn't really matter. Listen, is it pleasing to God? Is God pleased with it? My online activity. No one's ever going to know. Can I give you a newsflash? So many people know. They can get your device, they can track your IP, they know what you're doing. You think you're hiding something. It's like Rachel when she hid those images in the tent. You know who didn't know? Jacob. You know why I think he didn't know? Because he said to Laban, whoever you find them with, let them die. Do you think he would have said that if he…no. But God knew what was in the tent because years later Moses wrote about it. God knew. I've hidden this, I've…no, no. God knows. And the question this morning, is it well-pleasing to God? Not is it well-pleasing to my parents and I'm sure that if it were your parents they wouldn't be well-pleased. Not is it well-pleasing to my spouse, I'm sure if they knew they wouldn't be pleased. I'm saying God knows. And is it well-pleasing to God? The places that I go, the entertainment that I choose, the…listen, the list could go on and on and on this morning. Proving what is acceptable unto the Lord. Paul says, wherefore we labor. Paul knew he was going to heaven. There's no doubt about that whatsoever. Paul knew that as he's writing to these believers in Corinth that they too had trusted Christ as their Savior because he speaks in the plural sense. We know, we have this confidence. It's not a matter of whether I'm going to go to heaven. It's not a matter of whether I'm going to lose my salvation. You can't. You're secure in the hand of God. We talked about this very truth even from the text last Sunday morning that he's given to us the earnest of the Spirit in verse number 5. I have an inheritance. I'm secure in the hand of God. But he says, wherefore we labor that whether present or absent we may be accepted of him. And I hope this morning that from a single verse of Scripture that we can have that same level of desire that Paul communicates. I want to be accepted of him. I want to be well-pleasing in his sight. How can I please him? He's given us a Bible and he's told us how we can please him. Have you ever felt like I don't know how to please somebody? Maybe it's a boss. Yeah, you've been there. I don't know. There's nothing I can do to please him. God tells us exactly what we can do to please him. And he also tells us the things that do not please him. And so Paul says that I want to be accepted of him and therefore I'm dedicated to this. I am laboring. I am exercising. I am striving. This morning, are you striving to please your Savior? Let's pray together. Father, we love you. We thank you for loving us. We thank you for your Word. We thank you for this truth in the testimony of the Apostle Paul. God, I pray that you would help us this morning to have the same desire and the same level of commitment, dedication, that we would labor, that we would strive, that we'd exercise, that we might be accepted, well-pleasing in your sight. Thank you for saving us. Lord, we know that one day we'll see you face-to-face. And as we'll examine next week, we'll stand before you to give an account at that judgment seat of Christ. God, it's our heart's desire this morning, my heart's desire this morning to be pleasing in your sight. Help us to live every day for your glory. I pray that in these moments of invitation that you'd have your will in way, that we would be responsive, that we'd be doers of your Word. Well thank you for every decision that's made, for it's in Christ's name we pray. Would you stand with me? Heads are bowed, eyes are closed. Kimberly's gonna play quietly on the piano. And as she does, the altar is open.

segments.text: verse of Scripture this morning, 2 Corinthians 5 and verse number 9, and I'll give you a moment
to turn there, 2 Corinthians 5 and verse number 9 this morning. Notice the Bible says this,
Wherefore we labor, that whether present or absent we may be accepted of him. Paul just concluded,
as we studied last week, these first eight verses of chapter number 5, he concluded the section
dealing with the certainty of heaven and the reality that all the redeemed will be with our
wonderful Savior for all of eternity. What a glorious truth. Amen. What a glorious truth
that God has given to us in his word so that we could have the confidence and the certainty
that when this life is over, when I take my final breath here, that I can be, I can know that I'll
be in his presence and I will forever be with him. We talked about last week the expectation
of every believer. If you've been saved by the grace of God this morning, your expectation is
heaven. You have that confidence. As he says in verse number 8, we are confident, I say,
and willing rather to be absent from the body than to be present with the Lord. And we have
that expectation. But I said this as we concluded the message last week, that not only do we have
the expectation, but we think about the excitement that should cause, that the expectation should
cause us to have great excitement. Why? Because I'm going to be with Jesus. And so many people,
as I mentioned last week, they want to talk about heaven and what is heaven like and so on and so
forth. And there are many things that God tells us in his word with regard to describing heaven.
But I want you to understand this morning that heaven is only heaven because our Savior is there.
If you take all of the descriptive terms, all of the wonderful things, but if Jesus is not there,
then it's not really heaven. And the amazing truth is that we find in this section of 2 Corinthians
5, verses 1 through 8, that Paul, he ended the fourth chapter talking about having that
eternal perspective and immediately goes to heaven and thinking about what our future is.
I said this last week, on our worst day, in our worst circumstance, we're still going to heaven.

no matter who says or does whatever it is, I'm going to heaven. I'm going to heaven.

at my life and it would be well-pleasing in the sight of God. And Paul says that his desire
is that he, that we, because he's speaking to this church at Corinth, to these believers, that he's

then he says we. He's including these believers. And for us this morning, that we would say

his life and you trace his steps, that he earnestly desired that his life would please
his Lord. He knew that he was going to heaven, that was settled, that was certain, but he wanted to
